intro: Pimpinella arabica, commonly known as Persian cumin, is a herbaceous plant native to the Mediterranean and Middle Eastern regions. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, feathery leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. Its seeds, often confused with cumin, are used in culinary and medicinal applications. Botanically, it thrives in well-drained soils and prefers full sun, making it a hardy annual or biennial plant.
